all_data.speaker: Ana Bento
all_data.transcript: Pilar was saying, but I I think we cannot start talking about transmission chain without thinking about the pathogen or the infectious agent first, I suppose, before going for a kind of like abstract uh discussion on that. Um and then trying to understand I guess susceptibility because that also comes into uh into the equation. Obviously, I'm I'm kind of outing myself as a modeler. Um but kind of like susceptibility is is is kind of like the second biggest part I suppose because then that affects both whatever reservoir or whatever vector and whatever host we might have.

all_data.transcript: So you're talking about host susceptibility?

all_data.speaker: Ana Bento

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: Yeah, and then it I guess going back on that, then you're going to have dead ends. Um and there you're going to have some uh hosts that are not going to contribute to onward transmission. So the pathogen kind of like dies there under certain conditions whether it's because that um because of a behavior that um host cannot pass it on to another host or because let's say if it's a human, they go to the hospital and they cannot pass it on. So it's like what's the contribution to onward transmission and to maintaining that transmission chain. Um we can also think about that.

all_data.speaker: Joyce Jose

all_data.transcript: That's perversely cool when we think about spillovers because that happens every day. all_data.speaker: Matthew Hopken

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Matt supports his idea by explaining that the overlapping of pathogen, vector, and host in space and time is necessary for the transmission chain to take off.

I and actually someone that understands not only the human behavior, but how to look at individual behavior of specific populations and determine the interventions there. But I think that extends even to understanding rural culture and farmers and you know, I just think of the number of times being a city guy going on to farms and you know, they immediately know that and the distrust there. So, I think that that incorporation of behavior is critical to outbreak response.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: Yeah, and and on that I can tell you a story. I my work is very interdisciplinary because I'm trying to combine the the social dimension um and trying to understand that. So I've worked with economists, I've worked with um sociologist and most of my work on doing my PhD was in rural communities. And one of the things that we were not really paying attention to was the human movement or that it was a very cultural aspect. Uh so there was indigenous communities in the Gran Chaco region, which is really interesting if we talk about anthropogenic change because that's at the expansion of the agricultural frontier. So there's a lot of deforestation, human displacement happening. But one of the things that caught us our attention, we were like doing yearly uh entomological surveys to collect triatomines. And from one year to the next, people will move. Like they literally destroy their house, they're mud houses and build them somewhere else. We're like, we could not not find the house to do like a longitudinal surveillance. And and then we understood that it was just a cultural thing. It was also enhanced by the socio economic conditions. Um but it they were semi nomadic communities. So you cannot and that had a huge impact on the population of the vector because you didn't give enough time for the vector to um create high densities. But on the other side, you create really um the house are very precarious, so more opportunities for any bug outside bug to invade and have an infestation in that house. So it had a really interesting tradeoff just on without even thinking about how people get exposed to it, just on the vector population. And we were not really thinking about that because culturally to us it's like, well, you've been in this house, you're at least going to be there for a couple years. Uh but they would move frequently. And so we started working with sociologists trying to understand why because if we want to do an intervention and design an intervention strategy to spray the houses, we need to take into account that movement because it's not the same if you're spraying a house and it's going to last for the effect is going to last for this long, whether it's like, no, it's not going to last because in three months they're going to be somewhere else. Um so yeah, I do think that's a really key part of it and that's kind of what it actually drove my interest in trying to incorporate the human, the cultural and behavioral aspects.

I mean, by the time you got sequencing back, those animals are probably off to slaughter. Uh, so how do you go back to get those same animals uh to potentially, you know, tie in collection of live virus and isolation of live virus for future studies. I mean, it's almost got to be done at the exact same time.

all_data.speaker: Matthew Hopken
all_data.transcript: Right.

all_data.speaker: Ana Bento
all_data.transcript: Yeah, I agree. So in my experience with bovine tuberculosis in the UK, which is not even a country that is, you know, challenged by a lot of the resource problems we have in low middle income countries, that's exactly it. So we we understood a lot of the movement of of of cattle in that in that way precisely because we had satellites uh imagery and we we have this like policy where we actually have to track all the cattle, but even so there's always, you know, people finding ways of keeping their cattle off the registry so satellites satellite image was actually incredibly helpful at the beginning to find those missing links.

all_data.speaker: Matthew Hopken
all_data.transcript: Right.

annotations.express agreement: Matt Hopken is agreeing with Ana Bento's previous statement about using satellite imagery to track cattle movement, as indicated by his use of "Right."

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: Yeah, I I all comes back. I'm sorry. I'm I'm an ecologist. So to me I always think about about potential bias and like sampling effects. like if what we're seeing is an actually an artifact of our sampling efforts or is it real? So that's where I feel like we can use a lot of modeling techniques to find um like optimization algorithms to have a more robust um sampling effort um to just to start with. just where where's the high risk of detecting this spill over event.

all_data.speaker: Chuck Lewis
all_data.transcript: Is there any way to get past the target species approach? Like, um, you know, rabies is my first love. So I was thinking about rabies as well, but that that one's fairly easy, all mammals.

all_data.speaker: Chuck Lewis
all_data.transcript: Uh, but when you start looking at a novel pathogen like SARS, like, I mean, outside of, I mean, it's kind of my bread and butter to look at risk assessments and animal models and determine susceptibility. But outside of someone asking me, do pigs get SARS COV2 and me taking the virus and putting it into pigs and see if they get it, is there a way to narrow it down beyond, you know, just looking at our main production species one at a time. I I recall that when they did some of the receptor work for SARS COV2, I think they incorporated neural networks and AI uh into receptor binding um estimates to basically judge which species were more likely to become infected or not.

annotations.present new idea: Chuck introduces the idea of using computational methods like neural networks and AI to predict species susceptibility to novel pathogens, moving beyond traditional animal model testing, which is a novel approach not previously discussed.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Chuck recalls the use of neural networks and AI in receptor binding estimates for SARS-CoV-2, providing evidence that such computational methods have been successfully applied to predict species susceptibility.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Chuck expands on the idea of assessing risk and susceptibility by suggesting a way to narrow down the species to test for novel pathogens, building on the previous discussion about surveillance and understanding pathogen transmission.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: Yeah, I I would say it depends on the endpoint. If we're worried about just human risk or like human disease or just overall um wildlife health. Uh, because we always and and this is a conversation where we're always focusing about human disease. But do we just want to care about that or do we really want to approach like more sustainable health um in general in all populations.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: animals that are have some contact with humans and forget about the rest. So that's I guess another question.

annotations.present new idea: Pilar is presenting a new idea by questioning whether the focus should only be on animals with human contact or on overall wildlife health, which introduces a broader perspective on the scope of concern.

all_data.speaker: Matt Erdman
all_data.transcript: So I have a sort of a reductionist idea.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker is about to introduce a new idea, indicated by the phrase "I have a sort of a reductionist idea."

all_data.speaker: Troy Clavell Sutton
all_data.transcript: I mean we've got humans and we know the human genome and we know certain pathogens target certain parts of the body. Couldn't we start looking at homology protein structures on all of the proteins that are on cell surfaces and compare those across species? And you wouldn't even have to look at a pathogen. You could say, you know, what is similar and if you start seeing pathogens that are using similar receptors, you could make some guesses in terms of what human susceptibility is. Gets more complicated because there's also, you know, glycosylated sugars and things like that, but if you wanted to dream big and start trying to make predictions about what would be threatening to humans, that would be one way of going.

annotations.present new idea: Troy presents a novel approach of comparing protein structures across species to predict human susceptibility to pathogens, without directly analyzing the pathogens themselves, which is a new concept in the discussion.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Troy expands on the discussion about identifying potential threats to humans by suggesting a specific method involving homology protein structures, building upon the previous discussion about animal-human interfaces and surveillance.
annotations.propose decision: Troy proposes that they start looking at homology protein structures on cell surfaces and compare them across species as a method to predict what would be threatening to humans, suggesting a concrete action for the group to consider.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: So what are the similarities between potential species interacting?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Pilar is asking a question to clarify the previous statement about using homology protein structures to predict threats to humans, specifically asking about the similarities between interacting species.

all_data.speaker: Troy Clavell Sutton
all_data.transcript: Yeah, so you know, ACE without even think, yeah. With ACE2, you know, and you don't even have to think about it being a known receptor for a virus because we don't know a lot of the receptors. Just what is the the similarity between these proteins on the surface of cells?

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: Yeah. I I I think that would be a very interesting idea of like going from like the other perspective, not waiting for a pathogen to emerge. It's like understanding what it's what interacting species have in common including humans.

annotations.express agreement: Pilar expresses agreement with Troy's idea of looking at homology protein structures across species to predict potential threats to humans, indicating support for the approach.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Pilar expands on Troy's idea by suggesting that it's a good approach to understand what interacting species have in common, including humans, instead of waiting for a pathogen to emerge, building upon the concept of identifying potential threats proactively.

all_data.speaker: Matt Erdman
all_data.transcript: So we talked a lot about direct transmission, same place, same time, but if we go to maybe other indirect modes, foodborne disease, vector borne may not fit that same concept of same time, same place, what intervention possibilities may exist for those modes of transmission.

annotations.ask clarifying question: Matt is asking what intervention possibilities exist for indirect modes of transmission, given that direct transmission has been discussed.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: I guess there you can I add the the time variable of like lags uh because that's basically what it is. If we're thinking about something that it's persistent in the environment for whatever reason, um it's going to be a matter of time. Like the the time the the potential window of exposure kind of increases or it's lagged. Um so we can incorporate that into the transmission chain.

all_data.speaker: Ana Bento
all_data.transcript: Agreed, it's just seasonality uh and understanding perhaps more layers of, you know, seasonality for the host might not be the same as the seasonality for for the vector and also trying to understand those timings and how you can disrupt them for instance, uh which which is an area that's been kind of explored a lot uh for mosquito born and now it's becoming a thing for uh tick born as well, trying to understand uh coinfection because of those seasonalities and lags and understanding how it's the best way to disrupt some of those cycles precisely um understanding those lags uh and so on. So it goes back to uh understanding the ecology of the different components in the transmission chain uh and how you sustainably kind of disrupt them uh trying to avoid as many kind of like chain events that have other types of of consequences, right? So uh which you know, we've failed uh many times.

annotations.express agreement: Ana agrees with Pilar's previous statement about adding a time variable of lags to the transmission chain.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Ana expands on the idea of time lags in transmission chains by discussing seasonality, differences in seasonality between hosts and vectors, and how to disrupt these cycles, building on the previous discussion about indirect modes of transmission.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Ana supports her point about disrupting transmission cycles by mentioning the exploration of this area for mosquito-borne and tick-borne diseases, and the importance of understanding the ecology of the transmission chain components.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: Ana offers constructive criticism by acknowledging past failures in sustainably disrupting transmission cycles while avoiding unintended consequences, suggesting a need for improved strategies.

all_data.speaker: Matthew Hopken
all_data.transcript: Some of this goes back to also bringing back in the socio economic side of things and the human behavior um with vector borne diseases, right? Sometimes you deforest and that changes your mosquito community and maybe the vectors become more populous. Can we is there a front end intervention that's once again proactive that teaches farmers not to deforest in this way or some way that's still makes it economically viable for them but reduces that risk.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Matt Hopken expands on the discussion of vector-borne diseases by bringing back the socio-economic side of things and human behavior, which were previously mentioned in the conversation.
annotations.propose decision: Matt Hopken proposes a proactive intervention that teaches farmers not to deforest in a way that changes the mosquito community, aiming to reduce the risk of vector-borne diseases while remaining economically viable for them.

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez

all_data.speaker: Matt Erdman
all_data.transcript: What are examples of interrupting then?

all_data.speaker: Maria Fernandez
all_data.transcript: use the words interrupting the transmission after it's identified. So um there's so if we're talking about um like vector borne diseases for example is identify uh a falsi um or a hotspot that it's occurring at that point with uh mosquito borne diseases for example, this is done a lot of the time uh where you have you've identify a cluster and then you spray which is in in a way the population of the vector. Uh but you identify um that um hotspot that cluster and you act upon it before it it spreads to another cluster. Um you can think also about like detecting cases so you can try to stop that transmission to going into um another host. So for example, people uh will quarantine. It's a very old popular intervention to stop the transmission chain.

all_data.speaker: Matthew Hopken
all_data.transcript: Yeah, so I'd like to add to both of those points that um.

all_data.speaker: Ana Bento
all_data.transcript: because one is interesting point which is not necessarily depopulation but these discussions about like gene drive systems and are genetically modified organisms part of what we consider our interruption to these transmission chains and however everyone feels about that it's all pretty brand new um but it seems to have promise. And then thinking because there's a number of modelers in here, thinking about incorporating multiple types of data sets together into a single predictive model and these can be disparate types of models. some researchers in in my uh at my research center have done some work with um skunk rabies and they were able to show that both case data, you know, just positive individuals and then the subset of those being genetic sequences and then the phylogeography of those genetic sequences both predicted the wave front and the wave speed equally well with each other into a single model. They both in a single model and they both independently. And so coming up with multiple ways to sample. We don't always have to rely on genetic sequencing. Can we come up with something that is sort of a proxy sample that helps us understand these kind of wave fronts and transmissions and helps us get in front of that and then and then have this intervention moment early on.
